articles.headline: U.S. and Allies Aim to Forge Commitments to Ukraine That Will Endure
articles.snippet: The specter of a second Donald J. Trump presidency injects new urgency into the NATO summit this week. President Biden and other leaders agree Ukraine should have an “irreversible” path to membership.
articles.abstract: The specter of a second Donald J. Trump presidency injects new urgency into the NATO summit this week. President Biden and other leaders agree Ukraine should have an “irreversible” path to membership.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States and its NATO allies have agreed that Ukraine should have an “irreversible” path to membership in the alliance, enshrining the phrase in a document that was released on Wednesday during the alliance’s summit in Washington.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong, Julian E. Barnes and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: A.I. Needs Copper. It Just Helped to Find Millions of Tons of It.
articles.snippet: The deposit, in Zambia, could make billions for Silicon Valley, provide minerals for the energy transition and help the United States in its rivalry with China.
articles.abstract: The deposit, in Zambia, could make billions for Silicon Valley, provide minerals for the energy transition and help the United States in its rivalry with China.
articles.lead_paragraph: Peering into their computer screens in California last year, the data crunchers watched a subterranean fortune come into focus.

articles.headline: For L.G.B.T.Q. People, Moving to Friendlier States Comes With a Cost
articles.snippet: Laws targeting gender-affirming care have uprooted thousands. But places that are more supportive can also be more expensive.
articles.abstract: Laws targeting gender-affirming care have uprooted thousands. But places that are more supportive can also be more expensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Stefanie Newell decided to move to Denver last year, the choice was about acceptance. Feeling comfortable as a transgender woman didn’t seem possible in San Antonio, her hometown, in the midst of a flood of Texas legislation targeting the L.G.B.T.Q. community.

articles.headline: Inflation Cooled Further in June, Welcome News for the Fed and Consumers
articles.snippet: Consumer Price Index inflation was 3 percent yearly in June  and fell month-to-month, a sharper slowdown than expected and a relief for the White House.
articles.abstract: Consumer Price Index inflation was 3 percent yearly in June  and fell month-to-month, a sharper slowdown than expected and a relief for the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Consumer Price Index climbed at a moderate pace in June compared with a year earlier and fell on a monthly basis, welcome news for Federal Reserve officials who are watching for further evidence that they have wrestled rapid inflation under control.

articles.headline: After French Election, Voters Are Resigned to Cost-of-Living Crisis
articles.snippet: France’s parliamentary elections were intended to bring change, but many fear the political gridlock means their struggle to pay bills will continue.
articles.abstract: France’s parliamentary elections were intended to bring change, but many fear the political gridlock means their struggle to pay bills will continue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Celine Gallois is more careful these days about what she puts in her shopping basket. Prices at French supermarkets have jumped by nearly a third in the last couple of years, and two bags, filled mainly with basics including pasta, milk, meat and fruit, now cost her about 80 euros — the most she can afford to spend each week.

articles.headline: Can Movies for Grown-Ups Still Sell Tickets? ‘Fly Me to the Moon’ Is a Test.
articles.snippet: Directed by Greg Berlanti, the film amounts to a Hollywood experiment: Is there still room at the multiplexes for original movies aimed at grown-ups.
articles.abstract: Directed by Greg Berlanti, the film amounts to a Hollywood experiment: Is there still room at the multiplexes for original movies aimed at grown-ups.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Fly Me to the Moon” is the kind of movie that isn’t supposed to succeed in theaters anymore, at least if you listen to franchise-obsessed studio executives.

articles.headline: Even Disinformation Experts Don’t Know How to Stop It
articles.snippet: Researchers have learned plenty about misinformation and how it spreads. But they’re still struggling to figure out how to stop it.
articles.abstract: Researchers have learned plenty about misinformation and how it spreads. But they’re still struggling to figure out how to stop it.
articles.lead_paragraph: To fight disinformation in a chaotic election year, Ruth Quint, a volunteer for a nonpartisan civic group in Pennsylvania, is relying on tactics both extensively studied and frequently deployed. Many of them, however, may also be futile.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Stuart A. Thompson
